text: what's up everyone it's brace from Lang
chain and today I'm excited to show off

so what is the social media agent this
agent can take in a URL to some content
that could be a blog post um a Twitter
link a YouTube video or anything else
which contains some sort of content you
want to write a tweet on it's going to
then scrape the contents of that URL

formats it into a nice clean report

generate a Twitter and Linkedin post
using the images and the marketing
report and once it's done that it's
going to interrupt the graph pause and
it's going to wait for your feedback
your feedback can be accepting or
submitting it and then it'll go and
schedule that post to be sent out at a
later date and that way you can send in
you know 50 links have it generate 50
tweets in LinkedIn posts approve and
schedule them all on your Saturday and
then over the course of the next two or

um and it's going to look for the

uh which is not taken so let's say I

so now that we've seen how the social
media agent works and how you can set it
up locally let's jump into exactly how
it's built under the hood we're going to
examine the graph and talk about all the
different nodes and what they
do so as you can see here I have my
graph open in Lange Smith studio um or
sorry L graph studio and the very first
node that gets called is the off socials
pass through um and this is for the main
generate post node what this does is it
takes your user ID from Twitter and
Linkedin it sends them to Arcade and it
just checks to make sure that both are
authorized and you have the required
permissions to use them if they're not
then it interrupts with the authorized
interrupt we saw before and it says hey
here's an authorization URL please use
this to authorize your account once
that's done it goes to the verify link
subgraph this contains a few different
nodes for different types of URLs we
have one for tweets YouTube content
General content and GitHub content uh
for the advanced setup you'll be able to
use GitHub YouTube um and tweets uh but
for the basic setup is just going to use
the general content node because this
uses fire craw to scrape uh but we have
different nodes for GitHub YouTube and
Twitter and that's because for GitHub
links we want to actually use the GitHub
API to fet the readme contents uh and
then also some dependencies to make sure
that it's relevant to your use case and
the images if any for YouTube we use
Gemini 2.0 to generate a summary of the
video so we don't have to use some you
know YouTube uh to text trans transcript
package we can just send the video right
to Gemini it'll generate a summary and
then we can also use the YouTube API to
extract the thumbnail and then for
tweets we have another subgraph and this
is because you want to get the Tweet
content but then also extract any links
in the tweets and that's because you
could have some tweets saying hey this
is super cool check this out and then
there's a link um and you wouldn't want
to be generating your post and
validating your post based on on just
the content of the Tweet but you want to
also examine what the Tweet is
referencing so we get the Tweet content
we then extract any URLs and for those
we use the same verify GitHub YouTube
and general nodes that we did to verify
the links that were in the Tweet so
GitHub YouTube General content works the
exact same before and then once we've
done that we validate the Tweet which is
just saying okay given this content and
given the page content of the URLs uh is
it actually relevant for our use case
and this is a prompt you can customize
so so once you've validated and verified
that all the links you've sent in are
relevant um we're going to go to the
general content report of course if
they're not relevant it's just going to
end the generate content report node
takes in the page content or the YouTube
summary or the read me uh from the link
that was sent before and it generates a
marketing report that's what we call it
uh based on that content and we do that
before generating the post because we
don't want to be sending the LM just the
raw page content and saying Hey I want
you to take this unstructured raw data
generate me a nice tweet based on that
because it doesn't work very well so
what we do is we have this pass through
node which takes the raw data it
extracts the relevant parts of it and
then it generates a nicely formatted
marketing report based on that content
and then we use the nicely formatted
marketing report to generate the actual
post after generating the post if it is
longer than 280 characters after moving
the URL then we call this condensed post
node if it's shorter than 280 characters
we go right to the human node or if you
using the full setup mode the find
images subgraph which we'll discuss in
just a second if it is longer than 280
characters we call the condensed post
node and this can call itself up to
three times if it is not able to get the
post under 280 characters um and what
this does is it just says hey here's
this marketing report here's the
original uh post it's too long please
rewrite it to be slightly more condensed
in under 280 characters now once we've
done that if you're using the full setup
then you can you it'll call the find IM
Imes subgraph this has three nodes find
images validate images and rerank images
find images is going to do two things uh
one if it's not a YouTube video it's
going to take a screenshot of the page
for giab repos it has some custom
screenshot logic to only screenshot the
exact readme for everything else it's
just going to take one big screenshot
and of course for YouTube videos we use
the thumbnail then it takes all the page
content and whether that be markdown or
HTML it runs it through um the script
which tries to extract any links from
that content once it's gotten all the
URLs to the links it then passes that to
the validate images node uh we do not
pass the thumbnail or screenshot to this
node because we know it's going to be at
least somewhat relevant um and then this
valid images node just takes in all the
links which are found in the page and it
passes them to Gemini 2.0 and it says
Hey given this post and marketing report
are these images relevant explain your
reasoning and then explain which or then
list out which images are relevant and
we do this because let's say you have a
blog post you scrape that page and the
blog post has comments and these
commenters can have profile photos we're
going to be extracting the links those
profile photos from the raw page content
and we don't want to include those um in
the human node when we interrupt because
those are just going to be useless to
the user uh because they're clearly not
going to want to post that in their
final post so this is used as a node to
kind of filter those out and make the
end experience for the user a little bit
better next we call the re rank images
node this takes the images that were
valid and it ranks them from most
important or sorry from most relevant to
least relevant and that's the order that
we show them in the agent inbox UI so
that the the user using this can have
the most relevant images up top they
don't need to scroll or search through
the images um to find the relevant ones
and it just makes the overall user
experience a little bit
better once you've done that we call the
human node this node is what interrupts
and actually triggers the inbox item in
the agent inbox and then from here it
processes responding editing or
accepting nodes so if you respond to it
it calls an llm and it says hey does the
user either want to rewrite the post
update the scheduled date or do they
want or is this an unknown action based
on the LM response it will either uh
update the description saying unknown
action or it'll route to the update
scheduled date node the rewrite post
node um or then call itself after that
it goes back to the human node where
interrupts and awaits for the user
feedback back again once you have uh
approved the post or accepted it or
edited and submitted it it then goes to
the schedule post node uh this will do
two things if you used a priority level
for the date this is where it actually
goes and finds the uh nearest date for
that priority level that's available and
then updates the store to then save that
date so it's not used again and then it
calls a second graph to actually
schedule the post the way we schedule
the post is we're able to use the after
seconds parameter in the L graph SDK
when we invoke our graph um and that is
the upload post graph and essentially
what we do is we take the uh schedule
date the current date we subtract them
and get the difference in seconds and
then we can pass that to the after
seconds parameter um and that will
essentially not call the um the
invocation the run until that many
seconds has passed so if we have it
scheduled and like we saw in my examples
for 2 minutes then it'll be 120 seconds
delay um but it could be days weeks
months um and it will just wait until
that time is there and then will
actually call The graft the upload post
graph very simple just uploads the post
to Twitter and Linkedin um and then also
if you follow the full setup guide uh we
have a slack integration where you can
optionally customize it to send you
messages and slack saying hey this post
was scheduled and that's called after
you submit the graph and then actually
when you upload them it'll say hey this
post is uploaded or if it fails it says
hey this post failed to
upload the last graph I want or sorry
the second to last graph I want to look
at is the injest data graph now what the
does is we use this to set up a Cron job
which is tied to a slack Channel um and
in this slack Channel anytime we see
some relevant content or um a link to
something which we might want to write a
tweet on we just grab the link send it
to the slack Channel and then there's a
Cron job set up where once every 24
hours it goes and inest the last 24
hours worth of messages from that slack
Channel and then calls to generate post
graph for each of those messages and
that way we can asynchronously find
these links send them to the slack
Channel it'll then generate the post for
them U but we don't have to do it all at
once because it just happens once every
24 hours now the last graph I want to
talk about is the reflection graph very
simple graph essentially it's called
every time that you call the rewrite
post node and it takes the original post
your request and the Rewritten post and
it passes it to an NM and it says hey uh
the user requested some changes to be
made do you think we need to write a new
rule based on that users's request they
don't have to repeat themselves in the
future it then writes that rule and
updates the store and then every time
the generate post condense post or
rewrite post node is called we
automatically inject all those rules so
let's say the post is generated and it
includes a bunch of hashtags and you
don't want hashtags you would respond
you'd say remove the hashtags and then
this reflection node would examine the
original the updated post and your
response and it would say okay I think
the user does not want hashtags in their
post so it's going to add a new rule
saying don't include hashtags in the
post and then every um post after that
which is generated
it's going to have that rule in the
prompt so the LM will not do that and it
can learn from your feedback to generate
more customizable posts for your use
case so that's how you set up the agent
inbox locally that is exactly how it's
built and why we chose certain things um
I hope you all enjoyed this video and I
hope to see you guys using it soon
